page.title: 08COLONIES OF SEA BIRDS
page.content: BURRA IS SURROUNDED BY SEA AND THIS DETERMINES THE TYPE OF BIRDS WE GET.THERE ARE A NUMBER OF SEABIRD COLONIES IN WEST BURRA.90% OF ARCTIC SKUAS (BONXIES) ARE FOUND IN SHETLAND AND THERE ARE BETWEEN 25-30 PAIRS IN THE REGION . 900 PAIRS OF GENTLE -EYED KITTIWAKES (RIPPACK-MAAS) BREED HERE; NESTING FARTHER DOWN THE CLIFF.THE ARCTIC TERNS (TIRRICKS) ARE PLENTIFUL. THERE WERE 230 PAIRS HERE AND THE NUMBER HAS SINCE GONE UP.A LARGE FLOCK OF BLACK GUILLEMOTS (TYSTIES) CAN BE SEEN IN THE AUTUMN AND UP TO ONE HUNDRED HAVE BEEN SEEN IN THE BAY. OTHER BIRDS WHICH HAVE COLONIES IN WEST BURRA ARE THE FULMARS (MAALIES) AND HERRING GULLS (MAAS) WHILE AT THE FOOT OF THE CLIFFS CAN BE SEEN THE SPRAWLING SEAWEED NEST OF THE SHAGS (SCARF).
